head.title: No. 1 Suits Blue Devils Just Fine

hedline.hl1: No. 1 Suits Blue Devils Just Fine

block.p: DUKE 101, NORTH CAROLINA A&T 66

William Avery scored 11 points during a two-and-a-half-minute span in the first half as Duke rolled over North Carolina A&T, 101-66, last night in Greensboro, N.C., in the Blue Devils' first game since regaining the No. 1 ranking.

Trajan Langdon also added 11 of his 16 points in Duke's 57-point opening half for the Blue Devils (17-1). The Aggies, led by Jonathan Richmond's 15 points, fell to 4-10 and 0-11 career against schools from the Atlantic Coast Conference.
DUKE 101, NORTH CAROLINA A&T 66

William Avery scored 11 points during a two-and-a-half-minute span in the first half as Duke rolled over North Carolina A&T, 101-66, last night in Greensboro, N.C., in the Blue Devils' first game since regaining the No. 1 ranking.

Trajan Langdon also added 11 of his 16 points in Duke's 57-point opening half for the Blue Devils (17-1). The Aggies, led by Jonathan Richmond's 15 points, fell to 4-10 and 0-11 career against schools from the Atlantic Coast Conference.
Duke, which was No. 1 for the first two weeks of December before losing to Michigan, made 20 of 33 shots (60.6 percent) in the opening 20 minutes to grab a 27-point halftime lead.
The Blue Devils started each half with 10-0 runs and were nearly as dominant in between.

The Aggies did close to 22-15 midway through the first half before Langdon converted a three-point play, made a pair of technical free throws called against A&T Coach Roy Thomas, and Roshown McLeod's shot in the lane made it 29-17.
PROVIDENCE 58, BOSTON COLLEGE 54
Kendrick Moore hit four free throws in the closing 11.2 seconds as visiting Providence overcame a 12-point second-half deficit and downed Boston College.
The Friars had trailed by 43-31 with just under 16 minutes left, but held the Eagles to only three field goals in the final 17 minutes and one in the closing 10 minutes 12. seconds
Jamel Thomas led the Friars (8-8 over all, 3-4 Big East) with 17 points. Llewellyn Cole added 15 points and 9 rebounds.
Antonio Granger paced Boston College (10-9, 2-6) with 21 points and 11 rebounds, his second consecutive double-double.
CLEMSON 69, VIRGINIA 52
Tony Christie had a career-high 17 points as No. 25 Clemson held off visiting Virginia's second-half rally.

Christie's four 3-pointers helped the Tigers (12-6, 3-3 Atlantic Coast Conference) take a 40-22 lead with 17:38 to go. But Clemson managed only two field goals in the next 10 minutes as the Cavaliers (10-9, 2-4) pulled within eight points.
Greg Buckner then scored four points and Christie another three in an 14-6 run that gave the Tigers their fourth victory in five tries against Virginia. Buckner finished with 19 points.
MICHIGAN 65, MINNESOTA 57
Robert Traylor had 21 points and 12 rebounds as No. 16. Michigan temporarily took over sole possession of first place in the Big Ten .

Maceo Baston added 15 points and 14 rebounds and Louis Bullock 10 points for the Wolverines (15-4, 5-1 Big Ten). Michigan began the night in a three-way tie for first with Michigan State and Iowa, who play tonight in Iowa City.
Sam Jacobson scored 21 points and Kyle Sanden added 11 for Minnesota (7-10, 0-6).
XAVIER 72, JOSEPH'S 62
In Cincinnati, Gary Lumpkin and Torraye Braggs led a balanced attack by scoring 14 points apiece, and No. 19 Xavier turned up the defensive intensity as it beat St. Joseph's.
Xavier (12-4, 4-2 Atlantic 10) gained control early as Lumpkin scored six consecutive points and pulled away by rattling St. Joseph's (5-8, 1-5) with its full-court press and half-court traps.
James Posey and Darnell Williams added 12 points apiece for Xavier. Rashid Bey scored 16 to lead St. Joseph's, which has lost five of its last six.
CINCINNATI 60, TULANE 50
D'Juan Baker scored 8 straight points down the stretch as No. 21 Cincinnati held off a late Tulane rally for a Conference USA victory in New Orleans.
The Bearcats (14-2, 6-0) won their 10th straight game. The Green Wave (6-11, 1-4) lost for the fifth time in six games.
Cincinnati let a 23-point lead shrink to four before putting the game away at the foul line.
FRESNO STATE
Daymond Forney and Avondre Jones were suspended indefinitely yesterday, the latest setbacks to hit Coach Jerry Tarkanian's program.
The school issued a one-sentence announcement that they were suspended for violating team rules. Officials refused further comment as to the reason.
Tarkanian told one reporter that the Bulldogs would have to go on without Forney and Jones, who had been starters.
COLLEGES: MEN'S BASKETBALL
